dt: {bc}a trace, mark, or visible sign left by something (such as an ancient city or a condition or practice) vanished or lost

{bc}a bodily part or organ that is small and degenerate or imperfectly developed in comparison to one more fully developed in an earlier stage of the individual, in a past generation, or in closely related forms

pt: {sc}trace{/sc} {sc}vestige{/sc} {sc}track{/sc} mean a perceptible sign made by something that has passed. {sc}trace{/sc} may suggest any line, mark, or discernible effect.
{sc}vestige{/sc} applies to a tangible reminder such as a fragment or remnant of what is past and gone.

pt.t: boulders that are {it}vestiges{/it} of the last ice age

pt: {sc}track{/sc} implies a continuous line that can be followed.

et: Middle English, from Middle French, from Latin {it}vestigium{/it} footstep, footprint, track, vestige
shortdef: a trace, mark, or visible sign left by something (such as an ancient city or a condition or practice) vanished or lost
